text: <@U02L3JC4H5X> has joined the channel

Roughly you could say that most horse races are run at a comfortable pace with all the horses clustered together, then when they reach the last couple of furlongs they will sprint for the line and only then do the gaps between horses open up. Occasionally however, races are run where one or two horses will apply pressure much earlier on and the race will become strung out and the final gaps between horses will end up much larger than would normally be the case. What I want to do is be able to determine how strung out a race was early on, from historical data. I dare say it may be revealed by sectional times but they are only available for a few racecourses. So is there some other clue in data I could download/scrape/purchase? Perhaps in-running odds at the half way point?

elements.text: Roughly you could say that most horse races are run at a comfortable pace with all the horses clustered together, then when they reach the last couple of furlongs they will sprint for the line and only then do the gaps between horses open up. Occasionally however, races are run where one or two horses will apply pressure much earlier on and the race will become strung out and the final gaps between horses will end up much larger than would normally be the case. What I want to do is be able to determine how strung out a race was early on, from historical data. I dare say it may be revealed by sectional times but they are only available for a few racecourses. So is there some other clue in data I could download/scrape/purchase? Perhaps in-running odds at the half way point?

text: Absent TPD (which 75% of uk racing doesn't have) there's no data source that I know of.

elements.text: Absent TPD (which 75% of uk racing doesn't have) there's no data source that I know of.

text: Certainly IR odds won't tell you as there's so much else going on.

elements.text: Certainly IR odds won't tell you as there's so much else going on.

text: Watch the replays

elements.text: Watch the replays

text: How about average of IR odds over a few seconds in the middle of the race - then consider are the odds more spread out than the pre-race odds. You'd certainly think that the odds of any outsiders that are near the back of a stretched out race would see their odds lower and vice versa for a favourite that was near the front.

elements.text: How about average of IR odds over a few seconds in the middle of the race - then consider are the odds more spread out than the pre-race odds. You'd certainly think that the odds of any outsiders that are near the back of a stretched out race would see their odds lower and vice versa for a favourite that was near the front.

text: you can sum up the squares of the implied probabilities IR and divide by the sum of squares from the final pre-off implied probabilities to maybe get an indicator of how spread the field is. I would use that and try and confirm it on the races where you have sectional times. Not sure what the result would be though

elements.text: you can sum up the squares of the implied probabilities IR and divide by the sum of squares from the final pre-off implied probabilities to maybe get an indicator of how spread the field is. I would use that and try and confirm it on the races where you have sectional times. Not sure what the result would be though

text: I'd be astonished if you can reliably imply the spread of the field from the odds. The odds of a horse in running reflect way more than how the field looks in a simplistic way.

elements.text: I'd be astonished if you can reliably imply the spread of the field from the odds. The odds of a horse in running reflect way more than how the field looks in a simplistic way.

text: <@UGV299K6H> it would certainly be no more than an indicator, i wouldnt have my hopes to high either. But depending on what Mick is planning to use it for, it may still work. If he wanted to use "spreadness" to try and get a measure of how "solidified" a result becomes early in the race, it may work

text: So the IR odds idea may or may not work. Another random thought - I could make up a kind of "straggler quotient"... I.e. if multiple horses come in way way behind the pack (but their ORs were in the same ballpark as the average) then it may be an indicator that the race had a fast early pace.

elements.text: So the IR odds idea may or may not work. Another random thought - I could make up a kind of "straggler quotient"... I.e. if multiple horses come in way way behind the pack (but their ORs were in the same ballpark as the average) then it may be an indicator that the race had a fast early pace.

text: Honestly I don't think any of this is going to work but as an exercise it might be worth doing because you might find something else out.

elements.text: Honestly I don't think any of this is going to work but as an exercise it might be worth doing because you might find something else out.

text: I am wanting this early pace measure to help determine how much significance to place on the gaps between the horses at the finish. So a win by X lengths in a normal jog-then-sprint race should be seen as more impressive than a win by X lengths in a fast-all-the-way race.

elements.text: I am wanting this early pace measure to help determine how much significance to place on the gaps between the horses at the finish. So a win by X lengths in a normal jog-then-sprint race should be seen as more impressive than a win by X lengths in a fast-all-the-way race.

text: Are you looking to use this in some kind of fundamentals pre-off model?

elements.text: yes

text: Hmmm. I just think you're building a house of cards trying to imply the data points that you want from other things.

text: :slightly_smiling_face: You may be right. But no harm in trying if it's not too much work.

elements.text: You may be right. But no harm in trying if it's not too much work.

text: You can certainly use the overall pace of the race (which is widely available) but that won't yell you how 'strung out' it was. Even then there are plenty of confounding factors like the going and so on.

elements.text: You can certainly use the overall pace of the race (which is widely available) but that won't yell you how 'strung out' it was. Even then there are plenty of confounding factors like the going and so on.

text: I see that <@ULDAVFDRP> is typing though so that'll be a more specialist opinion.

is typing though so that'll be a more specialist opinion.

text: <@U02KTRHN7JQ> has joined the channel

If you have a knowledge of horse racing you can watch a race and tell which horse is running well and which is struggling. The horse that is going well maybe last but an experienced racing person will know that it will finish the strongest and overtake the strugglers in front. Gaps may be meaningful in motor racing but not in horse racing.

elements.text: If you have a knowledge of horse racing you can watch a race and tell which horse is running well and which is struggling. The horse that is going well maybe last but an experienced racing person will know that it will finish the strongest and overtake the strugglers in front. Gaps may be meaningful in motor racing but not in horse racing.

text: A performance on a given day probably cant be boiled down to one attribute. Youve got weight carried, going + actual going, jockeys, weight allowances, interference all sorts really. I think you will end up creating a feature that is way too specific and wont generalise. Furthermore if a horse cant place the jockey will walk the horse over the line and distances then can be misleading. What I will say is in-play odds can be used to determine how well a horse has run, even if it hasnt won.

elements.text: A performance on a given day probably cant be boiled down to one attribute. Youve got weight carried, going + actual going, jockeys, weight allowances, interference all sorts really. I think you will end up creating a feature that is way too specific and wont generalise. Furthermore if a horse cant place the jockey will walk the horse over the line and distances then can be misleading. What I will say is in-play odds can be used to determine how well a horse has run, even if it hasnt won.

text: In my head at least (not too sure the inplay boys will agree), if a horse has gone off at 10.0 (BSP) and in-play it lingered around 2.0 (for a decent amount of time) then obviously the markets chances has gone from 10% chance of winning to 50%.

text: If you just watched that plumton race there the jockey in second knew it couldnt win and knew it was going to be overtaken so eased the horse down massively and the horse infront pulled further away

text: So the lesson is... Gaps are more significant in an all-bunched-together-jog-then-sprint race than a stretched out race.

elements.text: So the lesson is... Gaps are more significant in an all-bunched-together-jog-then-sprint race than a stretched out race.

text: This probably applies more to flat than jumps - jumps have a tendency to always be stretched.

elements.text: This probably applies more to flat than jumps - jumps have a tendency to always be stretched.

text: I just think its way to complex to model and get anything trustworthy out of. As I suggested in the second message, using the odds relative to a benchmark / entry point probably the route to go.
